text: a witness, called for examination, having been first duly sworn, was examined and testified as follows: EXAMINATION

Good afternoon, Dr. Lippman. We were introduced briefly off the record, but for the record, my name is Kelly Kylis, and along with Jennifer Alexander, we represent the defendants in the case filed by Ms. Regina Johnson for which we have brought you here today. To begin, would you please state your name and business address.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: My name is Kenneth R. Lippman.  My office address is 809 North Charles Street. That's Baltimore, Maryland 21201.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Thank you, Doctor. Now, have you had your deposition taken before?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I have.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Very good. Well, since you have, I will just go over a couple very brief ground rules that you probably already know. The first, as Madam Court Reporter has just reminded me, we must speak slowly and clearly so that she can accurately record everything that we say. Secondly, all responses must be verbal, yes, no, or whatever the answer may be. Thirdly, it's very important that we don't talk over each other so that she can accurately record everything that we say. Finally, if you don't understand any of my questions, please let me know, and I will be happy to rephrase them.  It's very important that we are on the same page at all times so that we have an accurate and clear record going forward. Okay?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Thank you, Doctor. Let me show you first what I have premarked as Deposition Exhibit Number 1.  This is your notice of deposition, essentially your invitation to be here today. Have you seen this document before?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I have not.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Attached to this deposition notice, if you wouldn't mind taking a quick look, is a document schedule.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: This document schedule requested you to bring pretty much just a copy of your file regarding Ms. Johnson. I see you have some papers with you today. What did you bring with you today?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: This is basically the office file.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what does that include?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Well, there's -- there is one report from July 16, 2019.  There's actually a separate report that's not in here as well. There's the form that Ms. Johnson fills out when she comes into the office, a patient history form. There's a couple pages of my notes. There's a letter from Paula Valese. There's some -- there's some x-ray reports from GW. Some of the forms that Ms. Johnson signs when she comes in. Some of the forms that she didn't sign when she came in. And -- oh.  And then there's a letter from Mr. Covacevich, who unfortunately is not with us today.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Right.  Not that he's dead, just --
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Yeah.  Just for the day, just for the day and could not be with us.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Thank you.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Yeah. And then there's the -- basically the bill that my office generates. And then there's a binder of records.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Great. Now, the binder of records that you have, where did you receive those?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Well, it came with this letter from Mr. Covacevich.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay. Okay.  Now, the first item that you listed in the documents that you brought with you today is the 7-16-19 report?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I think that you said to me that there was another report. When you said that, what did you mean?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I meant just what I said.  There's a -- after I completed this report, I wrote another, sort of supplemental, additional report, which I don't think you have.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Okay?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And why did you not bring it with you today?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Because it just didn't get -- for some reason, it's not in the file, but I know about it, and then -- so I -- I can print it out -- I can read it to you.  In fact, I can read it off my phone to you.  It's just a couple -- maybe one paragraph or so.  But it just wasn't -- for some reason, it didn't get put in the file.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: So the file got processed and billed without it.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Understood.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Yeah.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: That second report, when did you complete it?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I think it has the same date on it.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: It's also from July 16?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: It's from July 16, yeah.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And why was it -- why did you do a second report on the same day?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Because after I completed it, then I realized that the impairment issue was not addressed.  And I don't think it was actually -- I don't know that it was requested in the letter or addressed in the letter, so I -- I guess at some point it crossed my mind that that would be an issue that would come up, so I just -- while it was fresh in my mind, I dictated something about it.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  If that report could be produced I guess to counsel and then to me --
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Yes.
speaker: MR. KEARNS

text: Well, I'll be happy to. I can't physically do it here.  I can read it to you if you want.  I mean, I would just read it in if you want just so you have an idea what it says.  But if you want me to just send it to you when I get back to the office, I'm happy to do that as well.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I think that would be fine. I mean, maybe just as a formality we can leave the deposition open for it?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: You know, you could ask him, you know, what the substance of the report is and any opinions that he may have from it.
speaker: MR. KEARNS

text: Yes.  I do intend to.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Oh, all right.  Well, we're going to get you a copy of the document, though.
speaker: MR. KEARNS

text: Right.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Yes.
speaker: MR. KEARNS

text: Yes.  I think that would be good.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: All right.  Well, while we're on the subject, can you tell me generally the substance of the -- what we're going to call the second report and --
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Sure. Do you mind if I reference it?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Sure.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: If I look at it? Okay. Do you want me to just read it to you or just tell you what it says?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: If it would be easier, Doctor, to read it, that would be fine.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: It says "Orthopedic Surgeon's Report." It's dated July 16, 2019.  And it references Regina Johnson. And it says (as read):  Following review of submitted medical records and the examination performed on 7-16-19, it could be said with a reasonable degree of medical probability and certainty that there is permanent impairment demonstrated.  This impairment is considered to be a result of the injuries sustained when she was shopping 2-2-16.  The impairment is represented in her current symptomatology, the physical examination and the imaging results.  This includes the myelomalacia reported by Dr. Hung. And it says "Kenneth R. Lippman, M.D."
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Great.  Thank you.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: You're welcome.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Doctor, while we're on this -- I'm going to just keep referring to it as the second report -- the last line of this report, you were discussing that your opinions were based on the symptomatology and included -- and you used a medical term.  I was hoping you could give me a definition of that medical term that you used in layman's terms, the diagnosis from Dr. Young.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Hung.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Hung.  Sorry.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: H-U-N-G. Well, the term is "myelomalacia," M-Y-E-L-O-M-A-L-A-C-I-A.  And basically that's a softening of the cord, the spinal cord.  It's when the cord turns to mush.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what causes that condition?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Well, it could be caused -- it's caused by some injury to the cord.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Now, we'll get into the mechanism of injury here in a minute, but I just want to focus on this while we're on it. Can you explain to me the basis for your opinion that this softening of the spinal cord is causally related to the incident that occurred at Walmart on February 20, 2016.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Well, there's no indication in the records that she had any type of problem, difficulty or concerns that would suggest the diagnosis of myelomalacia prior to the events of February --
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: 20th?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: It was 20th.  I just realized that this one says "02" instead of "20," so the one I read to you has the wrong date on it.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Okay?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: We can forgive that.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Yes.  Thank you. So prior to the events of February 20, 2016, she was quite -- she was physically active and had no symptoms that would be associated -- that would lead to entertaining such a diagnosis. And then when you go through the initial medical reports, the ones that are generated basically in the days, weeks and months following the injury, you see symptoms that are highly suggestive of this type of diagnosis. The -- there's a description of the initial injury, the unsteadiness that she had, the ataxia, the radiating symptomatology.  That and other symptoms are very suggestive of this type of diagnosis that was eventually made by MRI.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Right. And that diagnosis didn't come until the MRI in 2018; correct?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: That's correct.  There was not an MRI of the neck in 2016 or 2017, and to the best of my knowledge, there was not one prior to 2016 either.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Correct.  Okay. Now, based on the description you just gave me, it sounds like your -- and correct me if I'm wrong, but it sounds like your opinion is based on the fact that she did not have any symptoms of this condition prior to the incident but did after. Did you review any medical records of Ms. Johnson that predate the February 20, 2016 incident?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I did not.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I don't know of any.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Okay?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Therefore, was your -- is your assessment that she did not have those symptoms prior to the February 20, 2016 incident based solely on her history that she provided to you verbally when she came in for her visit?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: It's based on the history and the lack of records.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you review any records that -- of her medical history that predate the February 20, 2016 incident?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: No.  I don't know of any.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I mean, if there are some, I -- I'd be happy to look at them.  But as we sit here, I don't know of any.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So when you say "lack of records," that doesn't necessarily mean that those records don't exist, it's simply that you were not provided them to review?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I don't know of any that do exist or don't exist.  I just don't have any information, other than I asked her in some way if there was something like this that predated the events of 2016, and she didn't indicate that there were, and I don't know that any records have been provided or found or known of or exist.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Understood. Okay.  Thank you. Staying just for one more moment -- and I'll get into the other background questions that I want to ask you, but staying on your opinions as to this permanent impairment referenced in your second report that you've read to us from your phone, other than the information you've previously provided regarding the symptomatology, is there any other basis for that opinion that you can tell me about as we sit here today?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I'm sorry.  Could you run the question by me again.  I'm not sure I understood the question.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Yes.  That was a terrible question.  I saw Madam Court Reporter shake her head at me. I'm asking about the opinion in your -- what I'm calling the second report about permanent impairment.  You told me that that opinion is based on the symptomatology as presented to you by Ms. Johnson. Is there any other basis for that opinion that you can explain to me today?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Sure.  It's -- it includes the symptomatology, but it also includes the physical examination, all the examinations that were performed between February 2016 and now, in other words, what other providers found in those several years' time, and the imaging studies, as well as the nature of the injury, the history itself, and the lack of a prior history. So it's basically -- I mean, it's everything that's on the table as we sit here.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay. Now, in terms of permanent impairment, have you done any kind of quantitative assessment of her permanent impairment as you opine it to be?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So no kind of disability assessment or anything like that?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: No.  I haven't done -- if you're asking me if I put a number on it -- is that what the question is?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Yes, Doctor.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Okay.  The answer is no.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When you said that she has a permanent impairment, what does that mean?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: It means that the situation is unlikely to change to a significant degree and will continue to be problematic for Ms. Johnson.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Thank you. All right.  If I could take us back to the beginning and just ask you a few background questions.  And I do appreciate you reading us your missing report from your phone.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Sure.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Just very briefly, Doctor, can you give me your educational background, starting with college.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I went to college at Clark University, which is in Worcester, Massachusetts. After that, I went to medical school, Mount Sinai School of Medicine.  That's in the city of New York. After that, I completed a one-year surgical internship at Mount Sinai Hospital in New York City and then, after that, an orthopedic residency program at State University of New York Stony Brook.  I completed that in 1985.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Great. And are you board-certified, Doctor?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I am not currently board-certified by the American Board of Orthopaedic Surgery.  I have been in the past.  I have board certification from the National Board of Physicians and Surgeons.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Forgive me.  You are board-certified with the second entity you just named?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And which one was that?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: It's the National Board of Physicians and Surgeons.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And were you previously board-certified by -- what was the first entity you listed?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: You're talking about the ABOS?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Yes.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I have been on probably three occasions.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And is there a reason why you're no longer certified with them?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: My certification ran out at the end of last year.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you intend to recertify?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I'm planning on it.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And what is the difference between the certification with the ABOS and the national board?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I don't know that I could explain to you what the difference is.  It's just another organization.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you have to recertify with the national board?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: You do.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How frequently do you have to do that?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I'm not -- I'm actually not sure.  I'd have to look it up.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: But it's relatively -- like -- I don't know if it's two years or five years.  I really don't remember, though.  It's just something I would look up and figure out.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Sure. And in what specialty are you certified?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: In orthopedics.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Does that include surgery?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: It does.  It does, yeah.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you hold any state licenses?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I do.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Which states?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I'm licensed to practice medicine in the state of Maryland.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Is that it?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: That's it.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you maintain any privileges at any hospitals?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Yes, I do.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Which hospitals?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I currently have staff privileges at St. Joseph's and at GBMC.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  Since, unfortunately, I don't have a copy of your CV, could you just give me your brief job history. Where do you work now?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I'm in private practice, work out of two offices, the one that was the business address I gave you, and then I have another office that I work out of a half day a week on Eastern Avenue.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And do you own that practice?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I own that practice, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  How long have you owned that practice?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: That practice probably goes back to the late '80s sometime.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you hold any other positions currently?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I'm not sure I understand the question.  What kind of positions are you referring to?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Anything from teaching, another -- another practice that you work in?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: No, I don't work in any other practices.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you do any teaching?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you do any research?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: No. You mean scientific research? No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Have you published in the past?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I mean, there were some publications when I was in residency at that time, but I couldn't tell you what they were or -- but nothing since I've been in private practice.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay. Now, in your private practice, what do you do, if you could just briefly describe your job?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I do whatever -- whatever I can and whatever the day calls for. So I have an office-based practice.  I don't work out of a hospital, generally speaking.  And just basic orthopedic care.  I don't specialize in any particular part of the body.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: That was going to be my next question. Thank you. Do you have any administrative responsibilities as part of owning your practice?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Yeah.  I got to keep it going.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I assumed the answer would be yes.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Can you tell me how much of your time is spent doing administrative duties as compared to actual practicing medicine?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I don't really know, like I never really thought about breaking it down that way, but it's -- it's more time than it's ever been before.  It seems like every day it's more and more, but it's not -- I don't think it's the majority.  It's -- most of the time it's patient care, but that in and of itself generates administrative issues, so I'm not really sure where you draw the line between the two.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay. Do you perform surgeries?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I do.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What kind of procedures do you do?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Carpal tunnel releases, arthroscopies, mostly shoulders and knees, some joint replacements. That's what I do mostly now.  I mean, the nature of my surgery is not like it used to be.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What did it used to be?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I used to do a lot of spine work, don't really do spine work anymore.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Is there a reason why?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: There's a couple reasons.  I mean, it's just -- it just doesn't work out the same way anymore.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What do you mean by that?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: First of all, I don't -- patient population isn't the same, like I used to always see people that needed spine surgery and I just don't see that very often anymore. I used to work very closely with a neurosurgeon.  I don't work with him anymore. He left town, basically. So just -- it's just a different kind of practice than it was a couple years ago.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You said "a couple years ago." About when did your practice change from doing a lot of spine work to now being mostly shoulders and knees?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I'd say probably in the three to five-year range or something like that.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  As it is now, how much of your practice is spine work?  If you could put a percentage on it.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I probably haven't been in on a spine case in well over a year, so it's really not -- I don't -- the ones that I have I send out now.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay. And do you do any medical-legal work?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How much of your practice is medical-legal work?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Well, I guess you'd have to define what that is.  I mean, I guess -- I guess this is medical-legal work.  I don't see it as medical-legal work, but you see it in a different way. So I do evaluations some.  On different days it's different amounts.  Many days I don't see any at all and some days I'll see a couple of them, and so it depends.  But it's not a large percentage of the practice where I'll do a -- this type of evaluation.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Would you be able to put a numerical percentage on it?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I'd say it -- well, not really.  I mean, I don't have a statistical way of doing that.  But it's -- it's an infrequent part.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You mentioned that you brought with you today your billing records for this matter. Can you tell me how much you've billed or charged to date in this case?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Can we go off the record a second?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Yes.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: (Discussion off the record.)
So the charges for the visit of 7-16-19 total $1,813.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And that's just for the one visit?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Well, it's for the -- for the one visit it's $750, and then there's charges for x-rays and then there's a charge for medical record review, so it all adds up to 1813.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay. Do you have a rate sheet, or do you simply charge 750 an hour, for your medical-legal consulting work?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: So there's a -- I think I know what you mean by "a rate sheet," so there's -- there's a piece of paper that has certain charges on it for depositions, trials, things like that, medical record review.  I don't have it with me, but there is such a document.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  How much do you charge for deposition or trial testimony?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: So if it's charged on an hourly rate, my recollection is it's -- for this deposition it would be $750 for the first hour and $600 for each additional hour or part thereof.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Yes.  I'm trying very hard to keep this to an hour. What about trial testimony?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Trial testimony is sometimes billed on an hourly basis and then it's sometimes billed on a daily rate, and I don't actually know what it says about the daily rate, if it does.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay. Now, obviously you are here on behalf of the plaintiff. Do you do any work for defendants as well?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I have.  Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When is the last time you had a defense case?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I don't recall specifically, but within the last six months or so I would guess.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How much -- if you can estimate, how much of your medical-legal consulting practice is on behalf of plaintiffs versus defendants?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I would say that it's mostly plaintiff and occasionally defense.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Have you testified in court in a medical-legal capacity?  As an expert witness? I'm sorry.  That was a bad question.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Yes, I have.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When you testified in court as an expert witness, were you qualified as an expert in that court?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Which court was that or what courts, plural, if --
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I don't know that I could list all the courts I've ever -- I mean, you're talking about thirty-plus years, so -- but I've been accepted as an expert in the courts in Baltimore City, Baltimore County, Montgomery County, probably Howard County, Harford County, and I'm sure other ones, too, but I don't recall -- oh, in Southern Maryland, so -- as well.  I don't remember which county specifically.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay. What kind of cases have you testified in as an expert witness?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Basically cases that involve orthopedic injuries.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Have you ever not been accepted as an expert in a court?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: No.  I don't think so.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay. Doctor, what, if anything, did you do to prepare for your deposition today?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I went through the records that I had regarding Ms. Johnson and I read my report.  I also looked at the images that I have.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Those are the diagnostic images?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Yes.  The ones from George Washington.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Great. When you saw Ms. Johnson in 2018, did you take additional x-rays or other diagnostic imaging?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I did.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: That was on the bill, so --
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: That's what I thought.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Right.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Before I get to those, did -- in preparation for your deposition today, did you speak with plaintiff's counsel Mr. Kearns, who's where with us?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I did.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what did you talk about?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Well, I -- the first thing we talked about is that it's not Mr. Covacevich and he's kind of new to the case. Then it says orthopedic surgeon at GW doesn't want to do surgery. And then it says see I-N-J, so I think that would be injury, and then it says -- well, actually, it's not "see."  It's "sec," S-E-C, so that's an abbreviation for secondary injury, I-N-J, slash harm. So there was some discussion that she was referencing that the surgery might lead to further injury or harm.

He can tell multiple pain, two-pound left side dumbbell, five to eight pounds on right. Then it goes onto the next page. He told me I can do intervals of running. Then it says ortho surg said my knee looked like not -- and there's a word I can't make out -- torn something.  He said tears, said I was too young for back surgery.  They see the inflection where it is not good. Then with regards to neck, has this type of pain before.  Then it says both knees involved.  I fell in bath -- no.  Actually, it says, I fell on something that begins with a B. And then it says when ST came on top of me. And then on the side of the page I wrote in a box knee pop. Prognosis.  Sent me into a progressive state.  My shoulder are always tense.  N/B get stiff.  Pain.  Not just weather.  After -- oh, no.  I'm sorry.  Not just weather, and then it says difficulty turn to left last week. I try my own Pilates and stretches. I've gained weight, 55 to 60 pounds estimated, as not as active. Spasms in low back every morning, stiff low back every day.  Diff get OOB in morning. It cracks.  Up back crack.  In pain all the time. Take probiotics now, turmeric, MultiVites, joint Cosamin. text: I do.

text: Well -- so I think the simple way to understand that is that it's basically a bone spur.  When you see the bone production, that's a spur.  It's building up in that area. So that's what I'm referring to when I'm talking about productive changes.

text: Okay.  So you did note productive changes in the cervical spine.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Now, you just said that they look arthritic. Do you attribute those productive changes -- or do you have an opinion as to whether those productive changes are attributable to the injury that Ms. Johnson is claiming from the Walmart incident?

text: I don't think they are exclusively attributable to the injuries. So interestingly enough, when you -- when you read the initial x-ray report, the one that was obtained in the emergency room, they don't actually report productive or degenerative changes.  But when you look at the -- when you look at the images, you can see that there were some productive or degenerative changes, so this -- this was certainly an average or reasonable neck back in 2016, February 2016, when injured. So how much of the change is due to the natural aging process and how much of that change is due to the trauma itself, there's no way to differentiate those two.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  You wouldn't be able to give any kind of percentage?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: No.  I don't know that there's any way to give any kind of percentage.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  But it's fair to say that the findings that you observed on the x-ray reports are due both to just the natural aging process as well as the injury she's claiming?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Sure.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay. Now, it looks like you -- in the last paragraph of your report on page 4, you looked at x-rays of the left knee as well, and those are x-rays that you obtained as of that July 2019 visit; correct?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: That's correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And that x-ray was normal; right?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: From an x-ray standpoint, I would say that's normal.  Sure.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: No objective findings of any injury in the left knee based on that x-ray that you took?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: No, not based on that x-ray.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay. Now, it appears that you only ordered x-rays of the left knee, not the right knee.  Is that right?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: That is correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Was there a reason why?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I'm sure there was.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: (Document review.) But as we sit here, I'm not sure what that -- what the reason was.  Just perhaps because I thought those findings were more marked in the left knee than the right.
Which findings are you referring to?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: The physical exam findings.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: But that's just -- I don't have a note which addresses your question specifically.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  If I could take you to page 5, that first paragraph, it looks to me like you ordered an x-ray of the left shoulder and reviewed that.  Am I right?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I did.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And it appears that you noted some mild early productive changes at the AC joint. What does that mean?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Well, it means the same type of productive changes that you see in the neck. There's narrowing of the joint space with increased bone formation.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what -- do you have an opinion as to the cause of those productive changes?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: It's the combination of everything that's happened to that shoulder since the beginning of her time.  It includes the injury to the shoulder and also whatever else has happened to that shoulder over the years.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When you mentioned the injury to the shoulder, I assume you're referring to the incident at Walmart. What's your understanding as to how the shoulder -- and let me clarify the -- Ms. Johnson's left shoulder was injured during the Walmart incident?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Well, it was injured as -- when the stroller fell on her, in whatever position she was, at whatever height it fell from.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So what -- perhaps I'm trying to dumb this down a little too much, but what happened to the shoulder that caused injury, based on your understanding?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Well, I don't know that we fully defined what happened to the shoulder, other than it remains problematic and symptomatic. It's become very stiff as a result of the injury. It was originally caused -- I'm sorry. It was originally called a sprain.  I don't think that really fully defines the injury, but that's all the information we have to work with.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay. Have you seen Ms. Johnson since July 16, 2019?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: No, I haven't.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Had you seen her prior to July 16, 2019?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: No, I had not.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay. Now, Doctor, I'll take you to that last paragraph of your report if I may. The first line is that it appears to be your opinion that treatment to date appears appropriate, reasonable, and causal connection is demonstrated to the injuries sustained 20 -- I'm sorry -- February 20, 2016 and their sequelae. Which treatment are you referring to in your report in that paragraph?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Well, basically I'm referring to all the treatment that's in this binder, the treatment provided by GW and Spinal Balance.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And Spinal Balance -- we didn't get into that -- that is the PT provider that she ultimately saw beginning in 2018; right?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And is it your understanding that she was prematurely discharged from Spinal Balance due to noncompliance with the physical therapy program?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: No.  I don't recall the reason for discharge.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  If I -- well, allow me to represent to you that her records reflect that she was discharged for noncompliance with the physical therapy program. Does that affect your opinion at all as to your opinions that that treatment was reasonable and necessary in this case?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Why not?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I thought it was reasonable and she underwent treatment for a period of time. That's fine.  I don't know how the discharge would affect what happened before the discharge.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay. When you say in your report that the causal connection is demonstrated to the injuries sustained on February 20, 2016 and their sequelae, what sequelae are you referring to there?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Well, everything that she has experienced as a result of these injuries, the stiffness, the pain, the softening of the cord, the limitations of function, the need for activity modifications, the limitations of her activities, all that are the sequelae of this injury.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Now, does the fact that Ms. Johnson was noncompliant with her physical therapy treatments and with the recommendations of many of her doctors during her treatment -- does that affect whether the sequelae are causally related to the incident?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Why not?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Because the sequelae are a result of the incident independent of any treatment that's provided subsequent to that event.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay. Now, is it possible, Doctor, that Ms. Johnson could have gotten better if she had been compliant with her doctors' referrals for physical therapy and the physical therapy that she did finally begin to undergo?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Well, I'll object to the question, but go ahead and answer it if you can.
speaker: MR. KEARNS

text: Anything is possible, but I deal with probabilities.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you have an opinion to a reasonable degree of medical probability that Ms. Johnson would have gotten better if she had been compliant with the recommendations of her treating physicians?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I don't -- I don't know of any treatment that could have been provided that would have significantly altered this outcome.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Now, by "this outcome" -- I think I'll segue into your next line in your report, which is that long-term prognosis is considered guarded. Is that what you mean by "outcome," that Ms. Johnson has this permanent impairment that we've previously talked about today?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Yes.  I think that it's reasonable to state that what she experiences as of July 16, 2019 is pretty much the way it's going to be for her.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  You next state that ongoing needs for treatment are anticipated. What treatment is anticipated?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Well, I can't say with any certainty what treatment it would be, but I would not be surprised if there is treatment in the future. But exactly what it comes out to be or predicting what it's going to be, I'm not in a position to do that.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So if I could ask it in a better way, do you have an opinion to a reasonable degree of medical probability that Ms. Johnson will require future treatment related to these injuries?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: No.  It's a possibility, but I can't say with any degree of certainty that she will require treatment or what that treatment would be.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay. If you are called to testify at trial in this case, do you intend to offer any opinions as to whether Ms. Johnson had to miss any time from work?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: If the question comes up, I would address it.  I mean, it has been addressed in the records, and I think it was addressed appropriately in the records. So she did miss time from work, and subsequently there were workplace modifications, and all that seems reasonable and appropriate.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay. Okay, Doctor.  If I could end with this last, very broad question. We've discussed many opinions that you have today about Ms. Johnson's care. Do you have any other opinions that you would offer at trial as to Ms. Johnson's medical treatment?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Not that come to mind as we sit here, but certainly if you ask more questions, something else may come to mind.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right. If I could have a minute to look over my notes. Do you have any questions?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I don't have questions of the doctor. You need a CV and you need the second report.
speaker: MR. KEARNS

text: Yes.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Okay.  Those are the only things I can think of right now; right?
speaker: MR. KEARNS

text: Yes.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Thank you.
speaker: MR. KEARNS

text: Yes, that's all.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: All right.
speaker: MR. KEARNS

text: (Pause in the proceedings.)

Very quickly, either in your handwritten notes or maybe in the second report that will be produced, you mentioned the possibility of Ms. Johnson having surgery.  She had talked to one of her doctors about a surgery?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Yep.  Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What kind of surgery was she talking about?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: As we sit here, my recollection was that that was about the neck, surgery on the neck.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Do you have an opinion to a reasonable degree of medical probability as to whether she will require surgery for her neck, either now or sometime in the future?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay. Okay.  That's all.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: No questions based on her question.
speaker: MR. KEARNS

text: Doctor, you have the right to read this deposition before it becomes final. You can also waive that right and trust that Madam Court Reporter has accurately taken down everything. Would you like to read it?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: It's not a matter of trust, but I would like to read it.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Certainly.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I do trust you.  But just the same, I'd like to read it.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: We'll buy a copy of the transcript.
speaker: MR. KEARNS
